rsbNotes.title: Jer 11–13
rsbNotes.text: 11:1–13:27 Judah’s idolatry is a violation of the covenant and will result in captivity as part of the curses of the covenant.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 12:6
rsbNotes.text: 12:6 your brothers and the house of your father. See 11:21–23.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 12:7
rsbNotes.text:
12:7 heritage. God’s “heritage” includes both the land given to Israel (Deut. 4:21), and the people themselves. See vv. 8, 9; 2:7.

beloved. See 11:15 and note.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 12:8
rsbNotes.text:
12:8 like a lion. This first of a series of similes (cf. vv. 9, 10) shows how Judah’s nature has been changed.

I hate her. As often in the Bible, “hate” is the only alternative to love (Mal. 1:2, 3).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 12:10
rsbNotes.text:
12:10 shepherds. That is, foreign rulers.

pleasant portion. See Is. 5:7.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 12:12
rsbNotes.text: 12:12 no flesh has peace. The verse exposes the lie of false proclamations of peace (6:14).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 12:14
rsbNotes.text:
12:14 evil neighbors. Though Judah’s enemies are used by the Lord to punish her, they themselves will be judged.

pluck up. When God judges Judah’s enemies by removing them from their own lands, He also will deliver and restore Judah, the theme to be developed in Jer. 30–33.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 12:15
rsbNotes.text: 12:15 after I have plucked them up . . . his land. This prophecy is an astonishing turn in the thought, anticipating a restoration and salvation of all peoples. Jeremiah looks forward to the inclusion of the Gentiles in God’s salvation (46:26; 48:47; 49:6) as do other prophets (e.g., Is. 42:6).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 12:16
rsbNotes.text: 12:16 they shall be built up . . . my people. See Is. 19:25 for an equally surprising use of “my people”—for Egypt.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 13:1
rsbNotes.text: 13:1 linen loincloth. The “loincloth” symbolizes the close relationship between God and His people.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 13:4
rsbNotes.text: 13:4 Euphrates. A nearer location may actually be intended (possibly Parah, Josh. 18:23, close to Anathoth), whose similarity of name nevertheless suggested the Euphrates and therefore the Babylonian exile.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 13:7
rsbNotes.text: 13:7 spoiled . . . good for nothing. Its ruin depicts the corruption of the people, no longer fit for a relationship with the Lord.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 13:11
rsbNotes.text: 13:11 made the whole house . . . cling to me. The Lord spells out the meaning of the symbolic act as an illustration of His covenant with all Israel.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 13:12
rsbNotes.text: 13:12 filled with wine. Wine is here used as a symbol of God’s wrath (25:15–29).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 13:18
rsbNotes.text:
13:18 to the king and the queen mother. Probably Jehoiachin and his mother Nehushta (2 Kin. 24:8). This prophecy is thus close to the time of Nebuchadnezzar’s attack on Jerusalem in 597 b.c. (Introduction: Author; Date and Occasion).

has come down. See 22:24–26. This judgment spells the end of the historical Davidic dynasty, and seems in conflict with the promise to David (2 Sam. 7). However, see 33:14–26 for the future fulfillment of the Davidic covenant.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 13:19
rsbNotes.text: 13:19 The cities of the Negeb. These cities along the southern border were important defense against allies of Babylon (like Moab; 2 Kin. 24:2), but were unable to prevent the sack of Judah. They symbolize Judah’s pride (v. 17), shown to be hollow.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 13:20
rsbNotes.text: 13:20 the north. See 4:6. Judah is vulnerable from both north and south (v. 19).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 13:22
rsbNotes.text: 13:22 your skirts. A picture of public shame, as of a prostitute.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 13:23
rsbNotes.text: 13:23 Can the Ethiopian . . . his spots. A rhetorical question. It is typical of Jeremiah to assert Judah’s inability to repent and obey the Lord—hence his new covenant theology (31:31–34 and notes). See “The Freedom and Bondage of the Will” at 17:9.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 13:25
rsbNotes.text: 13:25 lot. The word “lot” recalls the lot cast for the division of the land (Josh. 14:2). Now it signifies expulsion from the same land.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 14–15
rsbNotes.text: 14:1–15:21 The people are so hardened in their sin that God will not answer even Jeremiah’s prayer for deliverance from the punishment of drought. In answer to Jeremiah’s question whether God has rejected Judah completely (14:19), God replies that the coming judgment is inevitable because of Judah’s sin, but He assures Jeremiah of personal deliverance from his enemies.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 14:3
rsbNotes.text: 14:3 cover their heads. A sign of mourning.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 14:4
rsbNotes.text: 14:4 no rain. The Lord either gives or withholds the rain (Deut. 11:10–15; 28:12).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 14:8
rsbNotes.text:
14:8 hope. The Hebrew word also means “pool,” a striking word in time of drought.

savior. Or deliverer, as in battle.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 14:9
rsbNotes.text: 14:9 called by your name. This calling explains the meaning of “for your name’s sake” in v. 7. The Lord’s honor is at stake in the fortunes of His people.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 14:10
rsbNotes.text:
14:10 says the Lord. God responds directly to the prayer of vv. 7–9.

this people. Perhaps significantly, God does not use “my people.”
